bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mrs. CAPPS:H.R. 1597.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article IV, Section 3, Clause 2: ``The Congress shall havePower to dispose of and make all needful Rules andRegulations respecting the Territory or other Propertybelonging to the United States; and nothing in thisConstitution shall be so construed as to Prejudice any Claimsof the United States, or of any particular State.''[Page H2914]

item.title: Northern California Ocean and Coastal Protection Act

item.title: West Coast Ocean Protection Act of 2011

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources.

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources.
Referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources.

summary.text: California Ocean and Coastal Protection Act - Amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to prohibit oil and gas preleasing, leasing, and related activities in areas of the Outer Continental Shelf located off the coast of California.

bill.title: California Ocean and Coastal Protection Act

item.title: California Ocean and Coastal Protection Act
California Ocean and Coastal Protection Act
To permanently prohibit oil and gas leasing off the coast of the State of California, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
